properties.headline: Special Weather Statement issued February 12 at 10:10AM CST by NWS Green Bay WI
properties.description:
A round of snow followed by windy and much colder weather is
anticipated during the next 36 hours as an arctic cold front
surges south across the area. Snow will accompany the front,
followed by a short-lived but fairly intense shot of cold air.

Snow associated with the front will overspread north-central and
far northeast Wisconsin through early to mid afternoon, then
reach central and east-central Wisconsin during the late afternoon
and early evening hours. Milder air will flow into the area ahead
of the front, possibly warming temperatures enough to cause some
rain to briefly mix with the snow at the onset over central and
east-central Wisconsin. The snow over north-central Wisconsin
will taper off during the evening, though snow showers off Lake
Superior will continue to affect the snowbelt. The steadier snow
will continue over east-central Wisconsin until at least midnight
before diminishing overnight. A widespread 1 to 3 inch snowfall
is anticipated across the area.

North winds will increase and become gusty as the colder air pours
into the area tonight. This will cause some blowing and drifting
of the snow, especially in east-central Wisconsin. Temperatures
will also fall sharply. By daybreak Thursday, the combination of
wind and cold temperatures will result in wind chills ranging
from around 20 below zero in north-central Wisconsin to around 5
below along the lakeshore. Wind chills around 20 below zero
can cause frostbite on exposed skin in as little as 30 minutes.

Additional snow accumulations after midnight will be minor and
probably limited to the Lake Superior snowbelt and areas near
Lake Michigan. However, the cold temperatures and blowing and
drifting snow will probably hinder the efforts of highway crews
to treat the roads, and result in hazardous travel conditions
lingering through the Thursday morning commute.

Allow extra travel time if you will be driving this afternoon
through tomorrow morning, as roads will be snow covered and
slippery in spots. Also plan on needing to wear warm winter
clothing Thursday due to the combination of wind and cold.

NWSheadline: HAZARDOUS TRAVEL CONDITIONS LIKELY TO DEVELOP LATER TODAY AND CONTINUE THROUGH THE THURSDAY MORNING COMMUTE
